Award.AwardTitle: Plant diversity in Las Orquideas (Colombia): exploration and discovery in the endangered and biodiverse Tropical Andes and Choco biogeographic regions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Colombia is one of the most biologically diverse countries in the world, but over the past 40 years major U.S. herbaria have observed a sharp decline (> 85%) in the number of Colombian plant specimens received. Consequently, entire lineages are inaccessible to researchers, undermining their understanding of plant diversity, especially in the Tropical Andes and Chocó regions, which rank highly in the world's top priority areas for conservation. Thus, an inventory of Las Orquídeas National Park, strategically located in the confluence of the Tropical Andes and Chocó, will be carried out. Plants will be collected in poorly known rainforests between 800-4,080 meters in altitude. Approximately 3000 plant species, some new to science, are expected to be encountered as a result of this study.

A catalog of the flora, the valuable specimens collected, and their on-line herbarium records will enhance the work of numerous researchers around the world. Training will be offered through internships in both Colombia and the U.S. To encourage and facilitate conservation of species at risk, educational guides will be designed for the park rangers and the Park's inhabitants. Finally, exhibits for the general public that aim to promote a greater understanding of the diversity of the region and the impacts of loss of biodiversity will be developed for museums in Colombia and the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Las Orquideas National Park (Colombia) is located in the confluence of the megadiverse and endangered Tropical Andes and Choco? regions. Despite being part of an area with one of the richest floras of the world, little was known about the park’s plants. Today, after several years of plant collecting and collections research, a database and website with specialized information about the flora is publicly available. Moreover, thousands of specimens of the unique Colombian flora were deposited in several herbaria in the Americas and Europe, ensuring their study for years to come.

 

So far, 176 families, 756 genera and 2476 published vascular plant species have documented in the endangered hyperhumid forests and páramos of LONP. This means that the flora of this national park is at least more than half the size of the entire vascular flora of Belize. To date, 4,703 databased herbarium specimens, 1,813 high-resolution images of herbarium specimens, 16,304 field photographs of plants, and information on over 2,000 taxa are all available online both via an electronic checklist (LONP vascular plants flora) and the virtual herbarium of the New York Botanical Garden. The herbarium records of the checklist are supplemented by their accompanying field descriptions and, when coordinates are available, distribution maps.

 

The herbarium specimens generated by the project were also made available to a network of dozens of collaborating plant specialists worldwide. Their study resulted in new plant records for Colombia and the discovery of many new plant species. The discovery and description of novelties of a rich but poorly known flora is a very lengthy process. However, to date 16 new species of vascular plants have been described (Amaya-Márquez et al. 2013; Garzón V. & González 2012; Garzón V. et al. 2012; Giraldo & Dalström 2012; Szlachetko & Klonowska 2013; Pedraza-Peñalosa 2015, in press; Smith et al. 2013) and many more novelties are expected.

 

Through fieldwork to areas never explored before, a new type of ecosystem for LONP was discovered; ours were the park’s first botanical collections of páramo plants. Páramos are protected by the Colombian legislation because they are the water source for millions of people. They are also protected because their island-like distribution makes them susceptible to global warming.

 

Lastly, to promote greater understanding of the Tropical Andes and Choco?’s natural history, impacts of loss of biodiversity, and the role of taxonomists and systematists in the race against habitat destruction and climate change, a series of five hardcopy mini-guides were published and freely distributed within LONP and the Colombian National Parks System. The photographic mini-guides cover plants important for conservation in LONP, common plants of LONP, epiphytes of LONP, orchids of LONP, and páramo plants of LONP.
